title: OpenLearning to list on ASX, beef up board
text:
"The listing process will take us to the next level and give us access to capital to let us grow the business and increase our portfolio."

Following the listing, OpenLearning will appoint former Navitas chief executive David Buckingham to the board, along with Twitter Asia Pacific managing director Maya Hari and Splitit chairman Spiro Pappas.

Patersons has been appointed as the lead manager.

OpenLearning's biggest markets are Australia and Malaysia. Locally it has nine of 43 universities as customers.

The company has had more than 2.4 million enrolments across 8900 courses and in 2018 it generated $1.8 million in revenue.

OpenLearning's course platform and consulting services are its largest revenue drivers, with the business only making a small portion of revenue from its courses marketplace.

Mr Brimo said the business, while small, was well-suited to public life, having settled on its business model and gotten used to providing investors with quarterly updates.

"We've experimented with a range of business models over the years and we know our customers value the OpenLearning platform and are willing to pay for it on a software-as-a-service basis," he said.

"For us, I don't seen short-term and long-term objectives as being at odds. We will be clear on what our focus is – enabling education providers to move online. All the other aspects [of being public] will work itself out."

Investors stay on board

The company will most likely be priced at 20¢ a share and it is targeting a market capitalisation of $25-30 million – slightly below the private market valuation of $33.5 million it achieved when the Malaysian companies bought in last year.

All of the company's existing investors, which also include tech entrepreneur Clive Mayhew, intend to stay on board through the float and not sell down.

The announcement of OpenLearning's listing comes as fellow education start-up Crimson announced a $US20 million ($29 million) capital raise last week, valuing the business that's run by 24-year-old Jamie Beaton at $US260 million.

The capital raised through OpenLearning's listing will go towards growing its customer base in Australia and Malaysia. Mr Brimo's goal over the next few years is to build the largest education technology business in the country.

"For us, Australia is our home market and it's responsible for the majority of revenue and still has so much untapped potential," he said.

"We haven't spread across all of Australia yet because we haven't had the marketing resources ... our short term focus is on growing further in existing markets."
description: Adam Brimo started MOOCs platform OpenLearning in Sydney in 2012, now he's listing it on the ASX with a high-powered board.
